When that happens, the ship undergoes an RCOHâ€”often cited as the most complex industrial project on the planet.Why does it take over 1,000 days and 20 million man-hours to complete?1. You have to "Cut the Ship Open"Unlike a car, the nuclear reactors are buried deep within the hull, protected by layers of steel and radiation shielding. To get to the fuel, engineers must literally cut massive holes through several decks of the ship. It is a "surgical" procedure on a 100,000-ton scale.2. Itâ€™s a Total Technology RebootThe "refueling" is actually just a small part of the work. Because this is the only time in 50 years the ship is completely opened up, the Navy uses it to:a) Replace thousands of miles of electrical wiring.b) Install the latest radar, sonar, and combat systems.c) Upgrade the flight deck and catapults to support next-gen aircraft like the F-35C.d) Blast and repaint the entire hull.3. The "Cool Down" and Safety ProtocolsWorking with nuclear fuel is slow by design. Once the reactors are shut down, they require days to cool before they can even be touched. Every single fuel rod must be moved with extreme precision using specialized cranes, as there is zero room for error when handling weapons-grade uranium.Video: mechanical_4u ç¾å›½åˆ›ä¸šè€…çš„å¾®åšè§†é¢‘
